transcript:
Therapist: It sounds like your relationship with your parents is really weighing on you. Let's explore this further. Can you give me an example of a recent situation where you felt guilty or struggled to communicate your needs?

Patient: Last week, my mom made a comment about how I've been spending a lot of time in my room and not helping out around the house as much. I know she's right, but I just feel so drained all the time. I want to contribute, but I don't know how to explain what I'm going through without disappointing them.

Therapist: That's a difficult position to be in, feeling like you're not meeting expectations but also struggling with your own mental health. Let's break this down using the CBT triangle. What thoughts were going through your mind when your mom made that comment?

Patient: I immediately thought, "I'm such a burden on my parents. They must be so frustrated with me." And then I started thinking about how I'm not working and how that must be adding to their stress.

Therapist: Those are some heavy thoughts, and I can see how they would impact your emotions. What feelings did you experience in that moment?

Patient: I felt really guilty and ashamed. I also felt overwhelmed and hopeless, like I'll never be able to make them proud or be the son they deserve.

Therapist: It's understandable to feel that way when you're holding yourself to such high standards. Now, let's look at the behavior part of the triangle. How did you respond to your mom's comment and those thoughts and feelings?

Patient: I just kind of shut down. I mumbled an apology and went back to my room. I avoided talking to my parents for the rest of the day because I didn't want to face their disappointment.

Therapist: Withdrawing and avoiding is a common response when we're feeling overwhelmed by negative thoughts and emotions. But that can also perpetuate the cycle and make it harder to address the underlying issues. Let's see if we can find a way to break that cycle using some of the skills we've been practicing. What do you think would have been a more helpful response in that situation?

Patient: I guess I could have tried to explain how I'm feeling and why I've been struggling to help out more. Maybe I could have used an "I" statement, like we've practiced, to express myself without getting defensive.

Therapist: That's a great idea. Using "I" statements can be really effective in communicating your needs and emotions without placing blame or triggering defensiveness in others. What might that "I" statement have sounded like in this situation?

Patient: I could have said something like, "I've been feeling really overwhelmed and drained lately, and that's why I've been spending more time in my room. I appreciate you bringing this up, and I want to find ways to contribute more around the house."

Therapist: That's a fantastic "I" statement. It acknowledges your mom's concerns while also expressing your own feelings and needs. How do you think your mom would have responded if you had said that?

Patient: I think she would have been more understanding. She's always been supportive when I open up to her. I just get so caught up in my own head that I forget to communicate.

Therapist: That's a really valuable insight, Liam. Our thoughts can be so powerful in influencing our behaviors, but we have the ability to challenge those thoughts and choose more adaptive responses. As we continue practicing these skills, it will become easier to catch those negative thoughts and shift to healthier communication patterns. Speaking of communication, you mentioned feeling anxious about the upcoming holiday season and family gatherings. Can you tell me more about what specific worries are coming up for you around that?

Patient: I'm just dreading the questions and comments from my extended family. They always ask about my job and my future plans, and I hate feeling like I don't have good answers. I'm worried they'll judge me for being unemployed and struggling with my mental health.

Therapist: It's natural to have some anxiety about facing those questions, especially if you've had negative experiences with judgmental comments in the past. Let's explore this further using the CBT triangle again. What thoughts are coming up for you when you imagine those interactions with your extended family?
